The start of Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine marks the beginning of a surge in hybrid warfare activities across Europe, including espionage and sabotage operations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from February 2022 to October 2025 reflects the escalation of hybrid warfare, with multiple European countries reporting coordinated espionage, sabotage, and drone incursions attributed to Russian operations.

keyTakeAways: Poland has arrested eight individuals, including three Ukrainian nationals, suspected of espionage, sabotage, and planning to send explosive packages to destabilize EU countries supporting Ukraine.

The arrests are linked to a broader pattern of Russian 'hybrid warfare' involving espionage, sabotage, and drone attacks across Europe, with countries like Romania, Lithuania, Latvia, and the UK also reporting similar incidents.

Polish authorities suspect the suspects were coordinating a network to transport explosives from Poland and Romania to Ukraine, with direct involvement or coordination from Russian intelligence services.
The United Kingdom and EU have accused Russia of orchestrating sabotage operations, while Moscow denies the allegations, calling them 'Russophobia'.
Poland has arrested 55 people over the past three years for suspected sabotage and espionage, all charged under Article 130 of the penal code.
The EU is proposing a 'drone wall' along eastern borders to counter increasing drone incursions, which have led to airport closures in Germany and Denmark.
Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen described the situation as the 'beginning of a hybrid war against Europe', signaling growing regional security concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Poland has arrested eight individuals, including three Ukrainian nationals, on suspicion of espionage, sabotage, and planning to deliver explosive packages to destabilize EU nations supporting Ukraine. Authorities allege these activities are part of a broader Russian hybrid warfare campaign, with evidence of coordination between suspects and Russian intelligence. Romanian and Polish agencies confirmed the suspects were involved in transporting explosives via international delivery services, and intelligence officials from multiple European countries, including the UK, Latvia, and Lithuania, have reported similar incidents. The European Union is now considering a 'drone wall' to counter increasing drone incursions, which have caused airport closures in Germany, Denmark, and Belgium. As part of a wider pattern of hybrid attacks since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in 2022, the situation underscores growing regional insecurity and calls for coordinated defense strategies.
title: Poland arrests suspected saboteurs amid fears of Russian ‘hybrid warfare’
